title: New Results from NA49
summary:
We present recent results of the SPS experiment NA49 on production of strange
particles and event-by-event fluctuations of mean $p_t$ and of charged particle
ratios in central Pb+Pb collisions at various beam energies (40, 80, 158 AGeV)
as well as in different collisions at 158 AGeV, going from p+p over light-ion
collisions to peripheral and central Pb+Pb.

NEW RESULTS FROM NA49
V. FRIESE FOR THE NA49 COLLABORATION
Fachbereich Physik der Universität Marburg
Renthof 5, 35032 Marburg, Germany
E-mail: volker.friese@physik.uni-marburg.de
We present recent results of the SPS experiment NA49 on production of strange
particles and event-by-event fluctuations of mean pt and of charged particle ratios
in central Pb+Pb collisions at various beam energies (40, 80, 158 AGeV) as well
as in different collisions at 158 AGeV, going from p+p over light-ion collisions to
peripheral and central Pb+Pb.

1

Introduction

A possible interpretation of the data collected by the various heavy-ion experiments at the CERN-SPS over the past few years is that a deconfined
state of nuclear matter is already reached in central Pb+Pb collisions at top
SPS energy (158 AGeV)1 . This immediately triggers the question whether
the transition point can be experimentally pinned down by varying the collision energy or the size of the collision system. The experiment NA492 aims
to investigate this question by studying hadronic observables, predominantly
strangeness production, for different beam energies (40, 80 and 158 AGeV)
as well as for different colliding systems, such as p+p, C+C and Pb+Pb at
various centralities. Further data taking at even lower beam energies (20, 30
AGeV) is foreseen for the year 2002.
2
2.1

Energy Dependence of Hadronic Observables
Kaon and Λ Production

NA49 can identify charged kaons by time-of-flight measurement near midrapidity and by the specific energy loss at forward rapidities. Λ baryons are
identified in NA49 by their V0 decay topology. The mt spectra for both
particles types are well described by exponentials. For the kaons, we find
comparable slopes (220-240 MeV) for all three energies, the slopes for K −
being slightly lower than those of K + . In the case of Λ, the slopes increase
slightly with beam energy.

2.2

Charge Fluctuations

Event-by-event charge fluctuations have lately been proposed as a signal of the
quark-gluon plasma6 . As a measure of these fluctuations, we have determined
D̃ = hNch ihδR2 i/(Cμ Cy ), where hδR2 i denotes the fluctuations in the ratio
of the numbers of positively and negatively charged hadrons, as a function
of the rapidity window ∆y. We obtain similar values around 4 for all three
beam energies, corresponding to the expectation for an uncorrelated pion gas,
whereas a QGP was predicted to yield values between 1 and 2. However, the
correction factors Cμ and Cy , which account for the finite net charge within
the acceptance and global charge conservation7 , are still under debate; hence
at the moment we do not draw a definite conclusion from the data observed.

3.2

Mean pT fluctuations

The observable Φpt , measuring the non-statistical event-by-event fluctuations
in the mean pT 10 , has been studied by NA49 at 158 AGeV for the set of
collision types mentioned in the previous sections. Fig. 4 gives the result as
a function of Npart for two different rapidity windows. At forward rapidity,
we obtain very small values of Φpt , almost indepent of Npart . Around midrapidity, however, we observe a rise in Φpt up to Npart ≈ 100, from where it
stays constant up to central Pb+Pb. This is contrary to the expectations,
which suggest a decrease in Φpt when going from elementary collisions to
larger systems where increasing equlibration suppresses the fluctuations. An
interpretation of this findings is still lacking.
